debate.para: Opening of South African Union Parliament : Prime Minister's Visit to South Africa. - Business of the Session. - Kalgoorlie to Port Augusta Railway. - Northern Territory Acceptance Bill. - " The Commonwealth of Australia for Farmers."

talk.start.para: . - I move -

speech.para: That a sum not exceeding£816,619 be granted to His Majesty for or towards defraying the services, of the . year ending 30th June,, 1911.

This Bill includes no special payments, and covers two months' Supply, based on the Estimates for last year. I promised the Leader of the Opposition that at some convenient time before I left Australia to visit South Africa I would make a statement regarding the work for the remainder of the session. As this is probably the last sitting which I shall be able to attend before I take my departure, I desire to state the business which the Government think is urgent and ought to be transacted this session. All of the measures on the notice-paper are important, and the Government are of opinion that their consideration will not occupy very much time. With the exception of the contentious measure now under discussion, they include the Sugar Bounty Bill, the Excise (Sugar) Bill, the Constitution Alteration (Legislative Powers) Bill, the Defence Bill, and a small Naval Defence Bill, which accords with the views of both parties, and is, therefore, not contentious.

talk.start.para: - Is it to give effect to the resolutions of the Imperial Conference?
- Exactly. It is complementary to the Defence Act.
- But the Government have not a Naval Defence Bill here.
- The object is to bring naval defence into harmony with land defence.
- The honorable gentleman will find that it will be a very big Bill.

- It does not seem so important to the Government as it does to the honorable member. The list of measures also includes the Northern Territory Acceptance Bill, the Lighthouses Bill, the Patents, Trade Marks, and Designs Bill, and the Parliamentary Witnesses Bill. There is a number of other small Bills which the Government would like to bring forward- I refer to a Judiciary Bill, a Tariff Anomalies Bill, a Penny Postage Bill, and an Oil Bounty Bill.
- When shall we see the Tariff Anomalies Bill?

- The Minister of Trade and Customs expects to have it ready very soon. There will also be a Bill to make some small amendments in the Electoral Act, and that long looked for Bill dealing with the Federal Territory. As regards :the Navigation Bill, of course the Government would be very pleased indeed if it could be passed "this-session.
- How long is the session going to last?
- I hope that, with the co-operation of honorable members opposite, the Attorney-General will be able to finish the session this month.
- Is the honorable member really serious?

- Oh, yes. These are small Bills. The Navigation Bill has been before the Parliament for six years. I am sure that honorable members on both sides recognise it is a non-contentious measure. We shall be very pleased if it passes safely through the Senate and reaches this House before the Parliament is prorogued. I should be very glad indeed to see the Bill put through both Houses this session. For the most part, these are small measures, and I venture to say that when honorable members opposite come to see and deal with them they will find that they can be disposed of in a very short time. Experienced Parliamentarians know that immediately the end of the session is in sight an enormous amount of work can be speedily dealt with, and I feel sure that that will be our experience this year. During my absence, my duties will fall upon the Attorney-General, and may I ask honorable members of both Houses to extend to him the consideration and courtesy that they have been good enough to show me. I thank the Opposition, and honorable members generally, for the uniform courtesy and kindness which they have invariably extended to me during my term of office.

.- The Prime Minister's opening remarks were naturally somewhat personal, and, therefore, I at once take the opportunity, on behalf of the Opposition, of wishing him bon voyage, and a very beneficial result from the interval he will enjoy before resuming his labours here. At the same time, let me say that we desire that this Parliament shall be associated with the message of congratulation that he will convey to the people of South Africa upon having attained in the councils of the Empire a position of authority equal to that already enjoyed by ourselves and by the other Dominions. We trust that he will also express our confidence in the future of that great country. Having regard to recent events, happily concluded by the union of all its Provinces, which have probably passed through a greater variety of grave dangers, during the lifetime of our cwn Commonwealth, than any other part of the earth's surface under the British flag, we trust that their new record may be one of unbroken peace and prosperity. We both anticipate and pray for them such a development as shall assist us to insure permanent peace to the Empire, based upon the closest union of all its races and Dominions, and guarantee their advance upon the high road of progress as one people. We, with difficulties of quite a minor character compared with theirs, encountering only political antagonisms or the misunderstandings and trials necessarily associated with the settlement of a new country, cannot, without much reflection, appreciate all that has been accomplished in that new Dominion. But that gives us great hope for its future. We may congratulate ourselves upon the fact that the coming Conference of the Empire will no longer be hampered by the inclusion of separate sets of representatives from each South African Province. Next year, for the first time, the whole of the self-governing peoples of the Empire will meet as Dominions in the Mother Country. It is needless to add more, except that I trust the Prime Minister will convey to the people of South Africa, in his own effective manner, an assurance that this is no expression of mere lip friendship, but a simple and sincere welcome into the home circle. We regard them as brothers, as joint heritors with us, of the Empire of which we are devoutly proud, and as a permanent pillar in its support. We look forward to the manifold tasks of civilization in that Dark Continent being enormously furthered by the union of the white peoples making that vast territory their habitation which offers magnificent opportunities for the fruitful labour of those who are, or will become, sons of the soil.

. - I regret that the Treasurer has not given us a little more information in regard to this Bill and the finances generally. It has always been the practice for the Treasurer in introducing a Supply Bill to take the Committee into his confidence, to speak of the revenue prospects, to intimate what revenue has been received, and to compare the returns with those anticipated when the Budget statement was delivered. The honorable gentleman, however, seems to have ignored all precedents. He merely threw the Bill upon the table, and saying, " There is nothing new in it," moved a resolution. That is neither convenient nor customary. I wish also to complain that no opportunity has been given to the House to discuss the Budget statement delivered by the Treasurer a month ago, as well as the papers then submitted for our consideration. Ours must be a very contented House. The whole financial position of the country was placed before us in the Budget statement, the debate on which was adjourned a month ago, and we have not yet had an opportunity to make any reference to it. Would the Treasurer expect such treatment from the Government if he were in Opposition? I think that we have been treated very cavalierly - I was going to say contemptuously
- That is not intended.

- Can honorable members point to any previous occasion when a month elapsed after the delivery of the Budget statement without an opportunity being given for its discussion? I do not think that such a record can be found in the annals of Australian parliamentary procedure.
- The honorable member can discuss the finances now.
- No one would be expected to debate the. Budget on a motion for temporary supply. That, too, would be unprecedented.
- But there is nothing to prevent the honorable member adopting that course.

- I wish that the honorable member would not make irrelevant interjections. The consideration of the Budget is one thing and the discussion of a temporary Supply Bill is quite another. I have waited for a month to speak on the Budget, but no opportunity has yet presented itself. Having regard to the fact that the Prime Minister is leaving to-morrow, and to the other business that remains to be considered, I do not propose to-night to deal with the general finances of the country, and will reserve any remarks I may have to make until the debate on the Budget is resumed. By that time, no doubt, we shall have forgotten the speech made by the Treasurer, and will have to turn to Hansard to refresh our memories. The debate upon the Budget ought to be initiated within two or three days of its delivery. That is the universal practice which should have been followed. I protest against the Treasurer throwing the Budget on the table of the House, and a month after affording honorable members an opportunity to discuss it, and then only under cover of a motion for the granting of temporary Supply. There is one question which I have waited, an opportunity to discuss, and upon which I cannot postpone my remarks any longer. I refer to the projected Kalgoorlie to Port Augusta railway. The sum of .£5,000 has been placed upon the Estimates in this connexion : but we have not been told the way in which even this small sum is to be expended.
- In preparing plans to enable a scheme to be submitted to Parliament for its approval.
- The honorable member was very quiet upon that subject when he had an opportunity to take action.

- I wish that the honorable member would not interject. He is merely a voting machine at the best, and has to do what he is told. To place a sum of ,£5,000 upon the Estimates in connexion with this important matter appears to me to be only trifling with it, especially in view of all the protestations we had from representatives of the Labour party during the recent election campaign in Western Australia.
- That is a very nice statement to come from the honorable member, seeing that he was in office for nearly ten years and did nothing.

- That statement is absolutely reckless and inaccurate. The Labour party are now in power and they are doing nothing. Its members are like "dumb driven cattle." The Government are not treating the country fairly by placing the small sum of ,£5,000 upon the Estimates in connexion with this important project. That money is really not required for any preliminary .purpose. A proper survey from Kalgoorlie to Port Augusta has already been made,- and plans and estimates of the work have been obtained. We have sufficient information upon which to let a contract for the construction of the line, and yet we are now told that an expenditure of. .£5,000 is necessary upon preliminary work. I wish to know exactly what the Government intend to do. We have been told by the Minister of Home Affairs that this ,£5,000 is required to defray the cost of preparing plans prior to the introduction next year of a measure authorizing the construction of the railway. But we have never had that statement authoritatively made by the head of the Government. For the Government to place on the Estimates the small .sum of £[5,000, with a foot-note setting out that the estimated cost of the work is ,£3,988,000, is unprecedented. They are not dealing with the matter in a practical way.
- We have done more in three months than the honorable member and his party did in ten years.
- The Government have been six months in office and they have done nothing. All that has been done was done prior to their accession to office.
- The Leader of the Government has given an assurance that the £5,000 represents necessary expenditure preliminary to the introduction of a Bill next session authorizing the construction of the work.

- Why has the Bill not been introduced this session? Is all the "stuff" which appears upon the business-paper more important than is this great project? If Ministers think so, why do they not say so? No reason has been assigned by the Government for this unwarrantable delay. If the work be a desirable one, why should its initiation be delayed, I have a right to ask that question. There must be some reason for delaying the undertaking for a period of twelve months. The Northern Territory Acceptance Bill has been submitted for the approval of Parliament. There has been no delay in regard to the proposed transfer of that Territory. Why, then, should the construction of the transcontinental railway from Kalgoorlie to Port Augusta, which was the crucial question of the general elections in Western Australia, be retarded ? The representatives of the Labour party told the electors of that State that, if they were returned to power, they would build that railway, and that, if the party with which I am associated were retained in office, it would not be built.
- The- honorable member was very quiet upon this subject when he had a chance to do something.
- I do not know why the honorable member so persistently interjects while I am speaking. I do not think that his action is either courteous or proper.
- The policy of the Government is to build that railway.
- But when?
- The Prime Minister has already given the honorable member an assurance in that connexion.
- The Prime Minister has not stated that next year the Government will introduce a Bill to authorize the construction of the railway.
- Yes, I have.

- I am very glad to have that assurance. But I do not see any reason why the work should be delayed. If it be a good thing to connect Western Australia with the eastern States by rail, why not set about the work at once?
- Is it not a marvellous thing that the honorable member did not think about this matter during all the years that he was a member of previous Cabinets ?

- How often have honorable members opposite promised that they would build the line at once if they were returned to power? All that I can tell the Honorary Minister is that I have done my best in the matter. I ask him whether he has done his best? At any rate, we did something. We had the survey made.
- The Government of which the honorable member was a Minister did not secure approval of the vote for that survey.
- We did, and experienced a great deal of trouble in getting that approval.
-It was the Watson Government which obtained that vote.

- It was not. The honorable member is absolutely in error in that statement. We did secure approval of the vote for £20,000 for that survey. We also provided for the construction of the line in connexion with the agreement for the transfer of the Northern Territory to the Commonwealth, thus affording the South Australian Parliament an opportunity of redeeming the promise which was made on its behalf immediately prior to the advent of Federation. But I do not wish to touch upon that question, because I might say something which would not help me. If a railway from Kalgoorlie to Port Augusta will be a good project next year, it must be an equally good project now. Next year the finances will not be in a better position than they are at the present time. Nor will the season next year be better than is the present season.
- The honorable member said that the Government would realize a revenue of ,£7,000,000 from the land tax.

- I never said anything of the kind. It seems to me that delay is a favorite device of persons who have not decided what they are going to do. I have been accustomed to that class of politician. They say, " Let us put it off till to-morrow, because we do not know what to-morrow will bring forth. Let us promise to do it next year, and when next year comes we can say that we fully intended to do it, but something has happened in the meantime, and we do not feel able to do it until the following year." In regard to a great project like this, which affects the whole of Australia, and is bound up with the federation of the States, it is absolutely wicked that all these years should have been allowed to go by without the railway being begun. It is still more wicked that now we have the opportunity of doing the work, having this year £4,000,000 of revenue more than we had last year, the matter should be delayed by them for another year. It is simply trifling with the matter, and not worthy of a progressive or enterprising Government. We have heard a great deal from honorable members opposite about the work. They made it their one cry. They said, " The party who were opposed to us have not done this work. Put us into power, and we will do it." They have been put into power, and we find that the work is not to be done now, but is to be put off until next year. I cannot understand this trifling, this indecision, this want of enterprise. One would have thought that they would seize the opportunity to associate their names with something that is useful to the country, instead of which they are associating their names with drastic legislation, which is imposing burdens upon people, annoying and disturbing everybody, doing no good, and not connecting their administration with any enterprising work. It is not statesmanship or enterprise to put off till next year what ought to be done at once. It would have been done at once if the electors had kept us in power. We should not have come down to the House, and said, " We expect to get only £1,000,000 from the land tax," if we knew that we would get over £2,000,000 from that source. I am very disappointed with the action of the Government in delaying this great project for no purpose or reason whatever. I am surprised that' the honorable member for Kalgoorlie, and also the honorable member fpr Coolgardie, should allow this to take place. The members of the Labour party who represent Western Australia in this Parliament have gone all over the country times out of number promising what they would do, and all we now get in fulfilment of those promises is the assurance that something will be done next year. Many things may happen between this and next year, and the Government may then say that they are not able to carry out what they fully intended to do at this date. The policy of the Government in this matter involves an unnecessary delay, wastes time, loses a good opportunity, does no good to any one, and is not likely to bring credit upon those associated with it. The Government have lost an opportunity of showing the people of Western Australia that they intended to fulfil the promise which was dangled before the eyes of the people to induce them to enter Federation, and has been dangled before their eyes by the Labour party ever since. I must express my regret that the delay has occurred. The action of the Treasurer in throwing these temporary Supply Bills on the table, and giving honorable members no information regarding them, is not conducive to the public interest. There never has been an occasion like the present, where, for more than a month, the finances of the country have been before honorable members, and an opportunity has not been given for us to discuss, them.

. - I do not wish to delay the Committee, but I think the right honorable member for Swan is entitled to a reply to at least one part of his statement. He was good enough to say he did not think I had ever made a statement of the Government's policy regarding the construction of the railway from Port Augusta to Kalgoorlie.
- Not as to time.

- I clearly stated to the House that the Government intended to bring forward a Bill next session to provide for the construction of the railway. The Government do not take such a light view of the matter as the right honorable member apparently does. We do not believe that a work involving an expenditure of £[4,000,000, and the construction of over 1,000 miles of railway, should be undertaken without considering the questions of gauge and manner of construction. Not only the gauge of the railway has to be decided, but plans and specifications will he necessary. ^
- The route is not settled yet.
- At any rate, the route is settled in so far that it is from Port Augusta towards a certain place.
- Do the Government intend to wait until a uniform gauge for Australia has been determined?

- No; but it would be very unwise for any Government to plunge into the construction of this line without duly considering the possibilities of the establishment of a uniform gauge between the capital cities of the Commonwealth.
- The same thing has been said for the last five years, and all the reports have been in the possession of the Government.

- I admit the value of reports, but it is more important to get an agreement between the parties concerned, if that is possible, before we commence the construction of such a large work as is contemplated. That is only one point, but the Government mean to undertake the construction of the line, and they recognise that in its construction there is involved a financial policy into which no Government with any self-respect, or with the interests of the people at heart, would plunge without knowing exactly where it began and where it was likely to end. The right honorable member for Swan is taking a light-and-airy view of the position when he says that if he had remained in power he would have commenced the work with pick and shovel, without considering the expense. That cannot be done.
- I did not say that.

- This Government prefers to carefully consider what it is going to authorize; and it will only authorize what it can finance; and it will finance its projects in such a way that the best interests of the public of Australia will be conserved and the money of the Commonwealth will not be squandered on immature schemes. 1 can assure the right honorable member that the work to which he has referred will be undertaken in a business-like manner as soon as the Government are in a position to lay plans before Parliament.

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: SMITH, Arthur
Mr BRUCE SMITH

talk.start.para: . - It is hardly to be expected that after spending half-a-day in entertaining the Dutch officers, honorable members should be in a very serious mood. I can readily understand that the entertainment has created a sort of lucid interval of cosmopolitanism in the Labour party, and that they are not quite prepared to settle down to local affairs. Notwithstanding the too conciliatory manner in which the Leader of the Opposition has treated the somewhat flippant statement of the Prime Minister in the form of congratulations upon the general results of the South African Union, I venture to think that the statement of the Prime Minister was unworthy of the occasion. He ought to recollect that there are in this House a number of honorable members who represent distant States, and who have been attending almost since the commencement of the session at half-past 10 o'clock in the morning, and remaining till 11 or 12 at night, on the distinct understanding that the session was to terminate at an early date in order to allow the Prime Minister to go to South Africa. But now we find the honorable gentleman practically waving his pocket handkerchief to this Parliament, and throwing before it a whole sheaf of business which is to occupy us for the remainder of the session. I wish to protest, as a member from another State who has been coming over regularly every week, and sitting here from 10.30 o'clock in the morning until late in the evening, against this treatment. If we are going to carry out the programme, which the Prime Minister has flippantly put before us, we shall be continuing our work in this Parliament right up to the end of December. In that event we shall have been led into this practice of early morning sittings on the understanding that the session was to close at an early date-
- To which December does the honorable member allude?

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: SMITH, Arthur
Mr BRUCE SMITH

talk.start.para: - I shall be satisfied if we rise in December of the present year, if the complete programme which the Prime Minister has laid before us were undertaken. It is easy for the Prime Minister, who is going off on a holiday, and is naturally looking forward with some pleasure to the reception which awaits him in South Africa, to talk in this fashion. But it is not treating this House fairly. Just look at this programme. It is very easy to say, " Here are a few short measures which can easily be dealt with." We must remember that in any event we have to wait until the other House has dealt with that 'very controversial subject, the land tax. Then we are asked to deal with various other " short" questions. First of all, we have the Naval Appropriation Bill. Then comes the Sugar Bounty Bill. That is a Bill which I do not hesitate to say will raise the whole question with regard to sugar. There will be a very long debate in this House as to whether the statutory arrangement by which the bounty, which works in conjunction with the Excise, and was to be gradually reduced, is now to be fixed. There will be a debate on the Tariff affecting sugar, which, ' so to speak, will revive the whole fiscal question associated with the Excise and the bounty. Then we are asked to dispose almost in a breath of the Constitution Alteration Bill. But we know that that question is going to raise the whole question of State rights. Does the Prime Minister really suppose that the members of this House are going quietly to pass a Bill by which it is proposed to submit to the people a question as to the advisableness of handing over to the Commonwealth the most treasured amongst the rights of the States, and so pave the way to a condition of unification ? I wish to tell the honorable gentleman that a Bill such as this will occupy at least a week in this House. Then we are told that the Defence Bill is " a very short matter." Perhaps it is. There is also the Northern Territory Acceptance Bill. The Prime Minister has not thrown the slightest light upon that question.
- The honorable member must not discuss the various measures.

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: SMITH, Arthur
Mr BRUCE SMITH

talk.start.para: - They have been discussed by the Prime Minister.
- The Prime Minister did not enter into details.

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: SMITH, Arthur
Mr BRUCE SMITH

talk.start.para: - I shall not go into details, 'but only deal with general principles. As honorable members know, p. very serious legal question has arisen over the Northern Territory Acceptance Bill which is estimated to cost this country £11,000,000 of money. Yet the Prime Minister waves his handkerchief as he leaves these shores, and says that it is a matter that can be dealt with " shortly " by this Parliament. I have no doubt the Parliamentary Witnesses Bill is a " short " measure, and it is possible that the Bill amending the Patents law and the Lighthouses Bill are also "short." But the Northern Territory Bill will revive the whole question as to whether or not the Commonwealth is justified in taking over this Territory, and also another point as to whether we ought to take it over until we know definitely that the Commonwealth is going to have the absolute right to direct the course of the railway. The Prime Minister has not thrown the slightest light upon that matter. Instead of that, he has told us that his Attorney-General has given a different opinion from that given by legal authorities in South Australia.
- I must ask the honorable member not to discuss that matter in detail.

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: SMITH, Arthur
Mr BRUCE SMITH

talk.start.para: - I have not any intention to do so, except to say this - that we know that the opinion of very eminent counsel in this State has been taken, and that his view is of course more valuable than that of the Prime Minister's adviser, who has expressed an opinion on the contrary side. I think that we are entitled to have some clearer and more concise statement as to what business is going to be taken before the close of the session ; because I am sure that no one in this House thinks that the programme mentioned by the Prime Minister is really going to be dealt with. In fact, the honorable " Labour " member for Maranoa laughed at the statement, and said, " How long are you going to keep us here ? " The honorable member, of course, realized the farce of putting a programme like this before the House at a time when we are supposed to be getting ready to close the session. We were asked to sit at half-past 10 in the morning for a particular reason. If Parliament is going to sit for another two or three months, so as to carry us on till the end of the year, I do not think it is fair to this House that such lengthy sittings should be continued ; and if the Prime Minister intended anything of the kind, I venture to tell him that he induced us to agree to those sittings on false pretences.

. - I must confess to have been very much disappointed at the statement of the Prime Minister with regard to the course of business. I understood that he intended to announce a programme for the remainder of the session which would take us at the very latest into the beginning of next month. Instead he has enumerated a programme of about twenty measures, some of them of overmastering importance - certainly some of them measures which affect the future destinies of this continent in a way that perhaps no other measures have heretofore done. But the Prime Minister is going away.
- I did not mention so many measures as the honorable member sta ted
-I think the honorable gentleman enumerated nearly twenty.
- Oh, no; the honorable member is quite wrong.

- I assure the Prime Minister that I am not wrong. If he will look at the list of the measures that have been announced, and are not yet on the business-paper, and will add them to those which are on the paper, he will find that there are eighteen or nineteen at the least. Who expects Parliament to rise at the beginning of next month, if it is in the meantime to dispose of a programme of that kind?

speech.para: I sympathise to some extent with the statement of my colleague, the right honorable member for Swan. I think that the work to which he has referred should proceed as speedily, and is, at any rate, as urgent, as the taking over of the Northern Territory. In my, judgment, the transcontinental railway is as much a part of the general Australian defence scheme as the Defence Bill itself is. The Northern Territory Acceptance Bill is also a part of that scheme. They are both parts of the general defence scheme, and should proceed together. At least, if there is to be precedence of one over the other, I think the Western Australian railway should take precedence in point of importance and urgency, as well as on the ground of its relation to the scheme for the nation's defence. It is even more important , than the taking over of the Northern Territory. It is of no use for the Commonwealth to take over the Northern Territory, or to think of doing anything with it in the matter of defence, until the railways are built; and, therefore, to delay those projects is to delay the real consummation of all that is desired. I thought that the Prime Minister would have curtailed very much the legislative programme for this session, we on this side having intimated our desire to close the session as soon as possible after he had left these shores. I have to congratulate the Prime Minister on his departure for South Africa on such an occasion ; but it occurs to me that he has overlooked one little duty. I hope the Prime Minister will not take this suggestion amiss; but it seems to me that before he left he might have invited Parliament to send a kindly letter of congratulation to our sister Dominion over the sea, considering that she is now entering on a new system of self-government - a system which we hope will bring the South African people all the blessings it has brought to us. It is not too late now to forward such a communication.

talk.start.para: - The honorable member for Ballarat did that when the Union was decided upon ; and I believe we have since taken some action. I have always felt that in South Africa I should be speaking for this Parliament and not for a party.
- But I think it would be fitting for this Parliament to send such a message. However, I merely throw out the suggestion, and express the opinion that it is not too late now to carry it into effect.
- I shall be glad to cooperate with the honorable member.
- The Prime Minister is going as our special ambassador to do what is suggested.

- There is another matter to which I should like to call attention. One great question which has intimate connexion with the defence of Australia is the question of filling our great empty spaces; in other words, I refer to immigration and land settlement. I should like to know from the Government what steps they are taking with a view to meeting this great national need? Are the Government doing any more than advertising for the purpose of getting people, of our own kith and kin preferably, to come to Australia, to people this vast virgin continent ? It can no longer be said that there is no land available in Australia. In a book issued on the authority of the Ministry for circulation abroad, with a foreword by the Minister of External Affairs himself, there is expressed the hope that people from overseas will be attracted to this progressive country.
- The honorable member does not disagree with that?
- Not at all ; I congratulate the honorable member on his conversion from a different point of view which he held, especially before the electors of Australia.
- The honorable member is quite wrong. I have not changed at all.

- The Minister who will succeed to the Leadership of the Government when the Prime Minister leaves for South Africa has declared over and over again on the platform, that not one penny-piece should be spent on immigration until very drastic land tax proposals had been carried into effect. The Minister of External Affairs, in the book to which I refer, has shown the absolute fatuity of an attitude of that kind ; because it is there stated that land is available, and particulars are given of our good social conditions, and so forth. We are told: in this publication, of great areas available for settlement, of social conditions that are all that can be desired - in short, that here is the El Dorado for the thousands of struggling hungry people of the older countries, and that the sooner they come here the better it will be for all concerned. I congratulate the Minister on coming back to a sane view of what are the conditions in our bright Australia. In the book, we ate told in' these words of our social conditions -

quote.para: There are none of the hardships attendant on congestion of population or severity of climate. The Australian in every section of the community is enabled to lead a comfortable and healthy life, and if he is ambitious to succeed in any avocation he is perfectly free from conservative conventions peculiar to older countries. In politics, every adult, male and female, has equal privileges, and the laws of the country are framed for the benefit of all alike. It would be absurd to affirm that there is no poverty in Australia, but it can truthfully be said that the number of absolutely destitute persons forms a comparatively negligible proportion of the entire population. No poor rate is levied in any part of the Commonwealth, for there is practically no pauper class to need it. . . . Taxation in Australia is extremely light in comparison with other countries, and in the case of farmers is practically insignificant.

speech.para: I pointed out the other day that that was not quite so ; but that our taxation here, including local taxation, is 21s. per head more than is the taxation in the Old Land., I do not wish to underrate this statement. On the whole, it is an admirable statement of our social conditions. The honorable gentleman says further -

quote.para: The best index of the general prosperity of Australia is that about one person in every three of the whole population has something in the bank. The total number of savings banks, with their branches and agencies, in the Commonwealth, is 1,717, and the depositors, to the number of 1,333,000, have accounts amounting in all to ^46, 147,289, which averages nearly twice as much as the deposits in any other country.

speech.para: I wish that my honorable friends opposite would issue this statement as a leaflet and scatter it all over New South Wales just now. It would be an admirable thing to do, as it would counteract many of the false statements which are being made from every platform by my honorable friends opposite and their friends, who are conducting an electoral campaign in that State at the present time.

talk.start.para: - The honorable gentleman was at it on Saturday night.

- I was at it on Saturday night, and I was quoting figures to counteract some of the tarradiddles the honorable member and his friends are constantly telling the people of New South Wales. I told them on Saturday night, amongst other things, that they had better take no risks or they might find themselves minus some of the many advantages which they now enjoy under the regime of a Government which honorable members opposite and their friends so bitterly denounce.
- The "leg-iron" Government.
- Order !

- I know nothing about any "leg-iron" Government, but I do know that Mr. Wade has carried some industrial laws in New South Wales which were agitated for, and supported to the full, by Mr. McGowen, Mr. Beeby, and all the rest of them.
- I ask the honorable member not to discuss matters raised by interjections.
- I do not wish to do so, but when statements are made about " leg-irons," I say that those who forged the leg-irons were those who voted for that legislation.
- Order ! I ask the honorable member not to continue to discuss that matter.
- The honorable gentleman said that the Post Office was the greatest sweating institution in the Southern Hemisphere.
- I said no such thing.
- I heard the honorable gentleman.
- The honorable gentleman did not. He is saying what is absolutely incorrect.
- I regret that I have to take the honorable gentleman's word here. I heard the honorable gentleman say it, and he was cheered to the echo.
- I defy the honorable member to produce a tittle of proof of that statement.
- I was present.
- 1 know that the honorable member was present, and I know that he went away a few yards, and, from a lorry, told the people that I was telling them lies.
- Hear, hear !

- The honorable member's lorry was decorated with garlands and bedecked with flowers. It blocked up the right-of-way, and the honorable member talked from it twenty to the dozen. He has just now made a statement for which there is not a tittle of justification. I am entitled to explain, in view of the statement which has been made, that what I did say was, that, whatever sweating there was before in the Post Office, it was, on the statement of Mr. Power, still going on under the regime of the present Postmaster-General, and that instead of the economic salvation they expected, things were not one whit better. That is a very different statement from the twisted statement which the honorable member has just made.
- There was no twisting.
- We cannot rectify all the evils of the past Government in a day.
- Exactly. That is what I was telling the people on Saturday night. I told them they had better be careful how they changed the managers of these institutions.
-Order ! I ask the honorable gentleman not to continue to discuss that matter.
- I shall quote what the honorable gentleman said a little later.

- I shall be glad if the honorable member will do so. He will not find that I said any such thing as he has just attributed to me. One of the things which honorable members opposite are saying throughout the length and breadth of Australia is that there is no land available for settlement in this country ; that the land is all held by land monopolists, and it is impossible to do anything in the way of immigration until very drastic legislation has been passed, and that that can only be brought into operation by Labour members in both the Federal and State spheres.
- Hear, hear !

- The honorable member for Hunter says, " Hear, hear," but let us see what the Minister of External Affairs says on the subject. Fortunately for us. we have one of their leaders who gives the lie to all these statements, and does it authoritatively and officially. He proposes to circulate what he has written on this subject throughout the length and breadth of the civilized world. Speaking of Western Australia, this is what he says -

quote.para: An enormous area of wheat land has been made available to the settler by the construction of spur railways, and when those lines which it is intended to construct are completed, a further large area will be opened.

speech.para: According to this statement, it is not the land monopolist who has the country by the throat. The difficulty is a lack of railway communication and facilities with which this Parliament has nothing whatever to do. 1 consider these statements are well worth reading; they will be useful a little later on when we are discussing some very important problems. A little later the Minister says -

quote.para: The price of Government lands ranges from 2s. 6d. to £2 per acre for scrub country, and from £3 to , £5 per acre for lands repurchased and subdivided for closer settlement.

speech.para: This refers to various parts of Australia.

talk.start.para: - I think only to Western Australia.

- No; the Minister, in making these statements, refers generally to Australia. We are continually hearing that no land is available for settlers, except at exorbitant prices, which put it beyond the pale of any small capitalist who seeks to get enough for himself and his family. But here the Minister says that there is plenty of land open for settlement - land that has been cleared, repurchased, subdivided, and is now ready for closer settlement - and the price is no more than £3 to£5 per acre.
- That does not apply to New South Wales.

- If the honorable member will be patient, I shall come to New South Wales before I sit down. The Minister has been through the whole of the States, and there are statements in this article relating to every State in the group, with a good many particulars.
- Why not get to the business of the country ? Why is the honorable gentleman wasting time like this?
- Then the land question is not the business of the country ?

speech.para: The honorable member has been telling the people from every public platform that it is the one question, and now, when we are discussing it, he says, " Why not get to the business of the country?"'

talk.start.para: - Let us go on with the business ; the honorable gentleman is only wasting time.

- What is the business of the country if it be not immigration, land settlement, giving to the people that birthright of which the honorable member has told them scores of times they have been robbed?
- I never mentioned the word once.
- Let me go on. The Minister of External Affairs further says -

quote.para: Within reasonable reach of the splendid railway services of all the States there is so much room for settlement that there is no present necessity for any one desirous of undertaking mixed farming going into the back-blocks . . . There is so much fertile land in Australia that there is no need for any intending settler to take up poor hungry soil.

talk.start.para: - Who writes this?
-I am quoting from a pamphlet issued by the Minister of External Affairs.
- Well, he does not know what he is talking about.
- To whom is the honorable member referring?
- To the Minister, or any one else who compiles such a statement. Whoever says that there is plenty of land available, does not know what he is talking about.

- That is the Minister's look-out; it is not mine. He does know what he is talking about. This is a fair and accurate representation of the state of affairs in Australia at the present moment. I have no quarrel with the Minister for issuing this pamphlet. We are getting the truth from his lips, and it is time that we had it, because the country has been saturated with lies during the last month or two; they are being circulated broadcast over New South Wales today. Now we have the answer to them from the mouth of the Minister of External Affairs in the Labour Administration of Australia. At page 35, speaking of land which is not improved, and which may be at some distance from railways, he says it is wise to leave all such land alone - and secure an area of partially improved land such as is made available under closer settlement schemes in all the States.

speech.para: He says that there is plenty of land close in to railways, and that such land is being made available in every State of Australia to-day. Going into particulars, he shows that in all the States " hundreds of thousands of acres " are available for mixed farming. He speaks of the capacity of our soil for growing barley, of the magnificent crops obtained, and the remunerative character of the employment in the various districts. He says .that there is abundance of room in Australia for settlers, and an inviting market open for all the horses that can be bred here, and advises people to invest money in land, and to go in for the, breeding of horses to supply the military requirements of India, as well as our own. Lucerne is another crop to which he refers. He says that -

quote.para: Experiments have proved that millions of acres of land that is offering £4 to £6 per acre in -Australia will f»row lucerne, and where irrigation is possible even better results can be secured than on the Hunter River flats.

talk.start.para: - I doubt it very much. The book is misleading, and if the Minister did his duty he would withdraw it.
- I suppose he has neither seen nor heard of it until now.

- There is h " foreword," signed " E. L. Batchelor. Australia, 15th Aug., 1910." so that there is no doubt of the authenticity of the publication. Dairying is another industry which is recommended. It is stated that -

quote.para: There is no difficulty in the newcomer securing on easy terms excellent unimproved land in settled districts at prices ranging from as low as ^2 per acre to £10 per acre.

speech.para: We are told that improved immigration schemes have been undertaken in Australia, and that - extensive tracts of irrigated lands are now ready for occupation in areas ranging from 15 to 20 acres to 200 acres and over. On such lands dairy farming can be conducted under the most favorable conditions.
The Minister invites people to come here and undertake dairying on the share system, though I have heard share-farming denounced from the house-tops by honorable members opposite -

quote.para: Men who contemplate undertaking this class of farming should submit the fullest possible details of their experience and qualifications to enable the officers of the Information Bureaux to make arrangements which will permit of settlement immediately on arrival.

speech.para: The inference is that an abundance of dairying land is waiting to be taken up on the share system. All you have to do is to show that you are a bona fide dairyman. and they will put you on a farm in which you will begin on the share system.

talk.start.para: - Why does not thf honorable member read the next sentence '^

- I see nothing in the next sentence qualifying in any way what I have already read. I do not pretend to make full quotations. The book is an excellent one, and, I hope, will have as wide a circulation over the world as it is possible to give it. It is the best book that has been issued for many a long day. All the details of Australian life are referred to, space being given for the discussion of the possibilities of Men market gardening -

quote.para: On irrigated lands that are now being made available for settlement in small areas ranging to 10 or 15 acres, the prospects for vegetable growing are particularly bright.

speech.para: Those who have been accustomed to CloSE culture can be 'accommodated ; there is plenty of land for them. Speaking generally about the land available, T find this statement on page 73 -

quote.para: There are, however, available for settlement in all States large tracts of partially cleared and improved lands, which can be prepared for cropping at trifling cost, and without any delay for burning off.

talk.start.para: - Does the honorable member believe that statement?
- Does the honorable member for South Sydney not consider it .1 true statement?
- I do believe it.
- Where are the districts ?
- There are millions of acres available in Australia today. But. let me. get cn with the quotation -

quote.para: Enormous areas are also available for selection under easy conditions, and in areas ranging to 60.000 acres for pastoral purposes, and in the shape of improvement leases.

speech.para: This is not the statement of myself, but of the Government, and, moreover, so far as I can judge, it is an absolutely correct account of the position of affairs in Australia. In South Australia " about 360,000 acres are now open to application in various localities." Referring to New South Wales, the booklet says -

quote.para: Large areas of Crown lands are available for selection in places, and farms may still be obtained under easy conditions, though most of the land of the best quality and nearest to the railway has been selected. Pioneering work would have to be done on these Crown lands now available before a farm could be evolved , but these disabilities were just as apparent to a great many of our present-day farmers, when years ago they drove their pigs in the primeval forest through which men had scarcely trod, much less built roads or laid rails.

In the North Coast portion of the Eastern Division, where 98 per cent, of the 4,000,000 occupied acres are given over to pastoral and dairying pursuits, there still remain 1,195,580 acres of Crown lands, and large areas of this, particularly among the head waters of the coastal rivers will, as facilities for transport increase, come under occupation as mixed farms, with dairying predominating. In the South Coast, though nearly 3,000,000 acres of Crown lands are unsettled, it is largely inaccessible country.

On the Tablelands, which occupy nearly 26,000,000 acres of the Eastern Division, over 5,000,000 acres still remain in the possession of the Crown, and though for the most part inaccessible country, areas large enough for farms are frequently found by the more adventurous settler.

talk.start.para: - " Still unsettled " is ;> different thing from being " available."
- These lands are only awaiting the construction of railways and other developmental works.
- - The book is wrong; it is misleading.

- Tn New South Wales, the writer says, there are available, in places for selection, large areas of Crown lands, and in other places a large quantity of land will be available as soon as railways have been built into it. I do not: know that my honorable friends are going to build railways into it, not yet awhile at any rate.
- The honorable member would induce people to come here and they could starve while the railways were being built. That is the effect of a work like that.
-The honorable member is always talking about people starving.
- I am talking sense.

- We are told in this book by the Minister of External Affairs that there are no starving people in Australia, that there is no pauper class here. Every statement which the honorable member makes is answered by the Minister.
- I said that if you induced men to come before building the railways, they would not be able to get on to the land, and consequently they would have to wait.
- There is an abundance of land on which they can settle.
- - There is not.
- There are millions of acres of land on which they ran settle.
- There were 400 or 500 applicants for every block the other week.
- The honorable member will find that there will be 400 or 500 applicants for every block so long as human nature lasts, and that system of balloting for land which is rife in our State obtains.
- Does the honorable member say that the majority were only gambling ?
- I do not know what the honorable member means by gambling. 1 do not call it gambling if a man wants in a bond fide way to get a little more land for himself.
- The honorable member admits that it was bond fide.

speech.para: Air. JOSEPH COOK.- I do not follow the honorable member's chop logic. All i say is that a number of these applications for land are from men who have land. That has been proved over and over again.

talk.start.para: - Sufficient land?
- Sufficient to keep them, yes. They are looking ahead, they have sons who are growing up, and want to get a little land tor them.
- They do not get it.
- The honorable member says that they should not get it.
- I say that they should.
-Then this is not gambling ; it is bond fide.
- Hear, -hear !
- All right. Then it is distinctly understood that many of these men who have applied to ballot for additional blocks have already living areas of their own.
- The honorable member says that they want land for their children, and cannot get it.

- They want the land for the time when the children will be ready to work it. The other day - on Friday, I think it was - we tried to induce the Attorney-General to leave alone the men who had a little land for their children, and he said, " No. If it is a consolidated block they shall pay the tax." There is just one other quotation which I wish to make, and this also relates to New South Wales. It is one of those statements which convey a world of truth and meaning -

quote.para: With the area of ordinary Crown lands, the lands made available under the Closer Settlement Act and the areas voluntarily released by the large landholders, a man with a little capital will experience no difficulty in getting a start in New South Wales.

speech.para: I might - repeat that for the sake of the honorable member for Hunter, as he seems to be sceptical about New South Wales.

talk.start.para: - I know that what I state is a fact.
- The honorable member may know a little about his own district, but he does not know all New South Wales by a long way.
- I know as much about the State as does the honorable member.
- I dare say. I am not setting up to be an authority. I am quite content to get behind the Minister on this occasion, and let the official figures speak for me.
- Because it suits the honorable member.

- These are not figures which the Minister has formulated. They are official figures, which have been given to him by the best authority he could find. He did 'not go to the honorable member for Hunter or myself, but to men who know a great deal more about these matters than either of us does, I take it.
- Apparently he knows more than the Premier of New South Wales does, because the latter does not contend that at all.
- It can be seen that the Minister has never read the work before.
- I have read it several times.

- Every one who is acquainted with the Minister knows with what thoroughness he performs his duties. He would be the very last man, I should imagine, to issue a booklet like this unless he had mastered every page of it.
- He has gone up in the honorable member's estimation.

- No. I have always had an excellent opinion as to the Minister's thoroughness and his general sanity of view in regard to many matters. I venture to say that he knows quite well what he has issued. He knows that the information contained in the book is true. The honorable member for Indi knows that too, only it does not suit him to admit it.
- I know that it is not true.

- If you could take the curse of party politics out of this business there is hardly an honorable member here who would not admit that these statements are perfectly correct. It does not suit their political book just now to do so.
- Why does the honorable member use these quotations to-night except for party politics?
- What is the honorable member quoting?

- I have been quoting from a work which I have described at least half-a-dozen times, and the honorable member wakes up and asks, " What is the honorable member quoting?" I am quoting from a booklet called The Commonwealth of Australia for Farmers.
- It is a grand title.

- Yes, and it is a beautifully got up book, which, I venture to say, will do an incalculable amount of good when it is circulated throughout the Old Country, as it well deserves to be. As to the States, the purport of the book is that there is ah abundance of land available on easy terms, and waiting only the advent of keen brains and strong arms to settle upon it an independent yeomanry, who will be able to defend it in the future, and to fill it with a happy and contented people.
- Is that the statement as to New South Wales?
- As to New South Wales, we have the statement that -

quote.para: With the area of ordinary Crown lands, the lands made available under the Closer Settlement Act, and the areas voluntarily released by the large land-holders, a man with a little capital will experience no difficulty in getting a start in New South Wales.

talk.start.para: - That is not correct.

- What a marvellously large number of land authorities we have in this Committee ! Honorable members opposite do not own a foot of land. I venture to say that not one of them has ever cultivated an acre, and yet they know everything connected with the subject. Turning to the Minister's statement as to South Australia, I again find that he knows what he is writing about. He writes -

quote.para: Large areas of land are about to be opened for settlement north of Pinnaroo and east of the River Murray, and on Eyre Peninsula, Port Lincoln district.

speech.para: Here is another general statement about Western Australia -

quote.para: There are millions of acres of unalienated lands in the State available for settlement.

talk.start.para: - That is a very vague statement.
- I cannot conceive of a more definite statement.
- But there is no statement as to the quality of the land available.
- Does the honorable member suggest that the Minister is trying to fool the people of the Old Country by telling them of land that is not fit for settlement?
- When land is available it is applied for over and over again.

- The honorable member does not know what he is talking about. If he turns to the official records of Western Australia, he will find that of the land made available for settlement last year, over 1,000,000 acres of good land, near railways and well watered, remain to-day to be taken up. The honorable member for Corangamite knows nothing of any part of Australia save the Western District of Victoria. That to him is a little world. I would remind him that Australia is a big place, and that even if a few men have obtained possession of the broad rich acres in which he is so much concerned, he need not imagine that they represent all Australia. At all events, I refer the honorable member to the Minister of External Affairs for information as to what land is available for settlement.

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: JOHNSON, Elliot
Mr W ELLIOT JOHNSON

talk.start.para: - There will be a great row in the caucus about this.

- I do not see why there should be. I could quote from this book many similar statements, but shall not weary the Committee with any more. I have quoted statements showing that there is land still available for settlement in every State, and that it is being made available by a process of private subdivision on reasonable terms. We have it that there is good lucerne land available at from £4 to £6 per acre.
- Does Sir Joseph Carruthers know anything about the lands of New South Wales?
- He does.
- He says that there is no Government land there available for the people.
- Where did he make that statement?
- In a speech at the Hawkesbury College to which I have previously referred in this House.
- The honorable member is talking of a speech made by Sir Joseph Carruthers at a college in my own electorate, about seven years ago.
- Not three years ago.
- It is seven years ago. Will the honorable member wake up and get the dust out of his eyes ?- Will he remember that Australia is going ahead while he is sleeping?
- If there is so much land unalienated in New South Wales, why have the Government been resuming so many areas?

- I must ask honorable members to discontinue these interjections. It is impossible for the honorable member to make a connected speech while they continue, and they ma.ke my task much heavier than it would otherwise be.

- In this official pamphlet, circulating throughout the whole of the civilized world, and the cost of which this Parliament is to provide, we have the fact set out by the Minister of External Affairs that there are millions of acres available for settlement in Australia at the present time; that land is being speedily made available in every form of tenure, and that we want only people from the other side of the world to come here and make homes for themselves upon the soil. In other words, this is a statement to the effect that there is an abundance of land available in Australia ; that it is cheap, easy of access, splendidly fertile, well watered, and capable of producing everything from the products of the station to the small cultures of the market garden. This land is available to-day to any one who cares to come and take it up. I hold, therefore, that there is 110 excuse for any delay in submitting a bold, forward, immigration scheme. I hope that this pamphlet is but the harbinger of such a scheme. I congratulate the Minister and ask him to take his courage in both hands and to place on the Estimates an amount in keeping with the" importance of this subject. There is no need longer to delay. Here are statements made on the authority of official departments in every State, and checked by himself, that there is an abundance of land available at the present time, and, therefore, we should cease for ever to argue in this Chamber that we need drastic legislation to make land available for the people.

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: SMITH, Arthur
Mr BRUCE SMITH

talk.start.para: . - During the previous debate on this subject reference was made to the desirable ness of crediting the Trust Fund with interest upon the accommodation secured from it. Will the Prime Minister say what he- has arranged in that connexion ?

. - I have stated from the first that it is advisable that any ordinary borrowing from a fund of this kind should bear the usual burden of interest. But the honorable member for Parkes will recollect that before the Australian Notes Bill was introduced I stated that this advance should be regarded as an exception. Rightly or wrongly, it is an advance to enable us to keep faith with the States by paying them in accordance with the provisions of section 87 of the Constitution up to the end of the present calendar year. Whilst I accepted with pleasure the amendment under which the money derived from the Australian Notes Bill is to be constituted a trust fund, and whilst I agree that any money drawn from it should bear a specified rate of interest, I do not think it is necessary to make that provision in this Bill.

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: SMITH, Arthur
Mr BRUCE SMITH

talk.start.para: - The Prime Minister proposes to do that.

- I propose to make that provision in reference to any investment other than this one. If the Committee feel strongly upon the matter, I have always said that I would make the desired provision in respect of this fund. But I have already intimated my view that we might use this fund temporarily, seeing that the amount borrowed from it will commence to be repaid from the 1st January next.

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: SMITH, Arthur
Mr BRUCE SMITH

talk.start.para: - To borrow from a fund without crediting it with interest is very loose financing.

- The honorable member must give me credit for at once consenting to constitute the money derived from the operation of the Australian Notes Bill a trust fund. No money can be used out of this Trust Fund without a Bill passing through this Parliament. No Executive can interfere with <t without the authority of Parliament. While I regret that it is not proposed to pay interest on the amount of Trust money that will be used for this temporary purpose

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: SMITH, Arthur
Mr BRUCE SMITH

talk.start.para: - What is the disadvantage in paying it? It will only be a bookkeeping credit, but it will keep the fund in its "proper position.

- I quite agree with the honorable member, but it would be advisable to state the rate of interest in the Bill if we wish to start that principle now. There are other Trust Funds, and the purposes for which the money is to be used are carefully prescribed. That applies to the Australian Notes Trust Fund. The money in that fund may be invested in British Consols, Commonwealth or State stock, or may be temporarily placed on deposit in the banks. It would, perhaps, be better not to provide for the payment of interest in this Bill, but any other advance from this fund should, I think, bear the usual rate of interest.

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: SMITH, Arthur
Mr BRUCE SMITH

talk.start.para: - It is a very simple thing to amend the Bill to provide for it.

- Very well; if honorable members strongly desire it, I would rather do it than have any doubt about it. Although it is clear "enough that any money that is to be taken from the Australian Notes Trust Fund is not to be part of the 25 per cent, gold reserve. T shall put in an amendment which will make that absolutely certain. That is a matter that ought not to be left in any doubt. 'It should be stated in clear and distinct language that this Bill will not permit of any of the 25 per cent, gold reserve being taken.
